cluster_classes.class_description: Astrophysical phenomena involving gravitational waves, including the waves themselves and their production in compact-object mergers.
cluster_classes.evidence_excerpt: Ripples in spacetime ... produced by ... merger of two black holes

members.entity_description: Ripples in spacetime produced by accelerating masses, such as merging black holes.
Astrophysical event where two black holes coalesce, emitting gravitational waves.

cluster_classes.class_description: The observational infrastructure and landmark detection event associated with the first direct observation of gravitational waves in 2015.
cluster_classes.evidence_excerpt: The discovery of gravitational waves by the LIGO observatory in 2015

members.entity_description: Laser Interferometer Gravitational-Wave Observatory that first detected gravitational waves.
First observation of gravitational waves by LIGO, confirming key predictions of general relativity.

cluster_classes.class_description: Concepts describing how the passage of time differs in strong versus weak gravitational fields near massive objects like black holes.
cluster_classes.evidence_excerpt: Time slows down near a black hole relative to observers further away.

members.entity_description: Relativistic effect where time passes more slowly in stronger gravitational fields compared to weaker ones.
Rate at which time passes in the strong gravitational field close to a black hole.
Rate of time passage experienced by observers distant from the black hole’s gravitational field.

cluster_classes.class_description: Physical phenomena related to gravitational attraction, including general gravity and the specific gravitational pull of black holes.
cluster_classes.evidence_excerpt: gravity ... governing the black hole’s pull; the gravitational field of a black hole that determines the event horizon

members.entity_name: gravitational pull of a black hole
members.entity_description: The intense gravitational field generated by a black hole, strong enough to warp spacetime and prevent escape beyond the event horizon.
Attractive force causing the star to collapse and governing the black hole’s pull.

splits.name: Compact Binary Mergers as Gravitational-Wave Sources
splits.description: Astrophysical events where compact objects such as black holes or neutron stars merge, emitting gravitational waves.

args.justification: The original class mixes a physical phenomenon (gravitational waves) with a specific source event type (merger of two black holes); splitting isolates the event subclass for cleaner semantics.

args.new_description: Ripples in spacetime produced by accelerating masses, such as merging black holes, neutron stars, or other compact objects.
args.justification: After splitting off merger events, the remaining entity is the physical phenomenon of gravitational waves, so the class should be renamed and grouped under a general gravitation/relativity class group.

args.new_description: Astrophysical merger events of compact objects, such as black holes, that act as sources of gravitational waves.
args.justification: The split-out class specifically represents compact-object merger events that generate gravitational waves and belongs under the same broader gravitation/relativity domain.
The LIGO observatory and the 2015 gravitational-wave discovery are part of the same scientific domain as other gravitation and general relativity phenomena, so they should share the same class group.
Gravitational time dilation is a core prediction of general relativity and fits naturally within a Gravitation and General Relativity class group shared with related gravitational phenomena.
General gravity and the gravitational pull of black holes are central gravitational phenomena and should be grouped with other classes under a unified Gravitation and General Relativity class group.

executed_decisions.justification: The original class mixes a physical phenomenon (gravitational waves) with a specific source event type (merger of two black holes); splitting isolates the event subclass for cleaner semantics.

executed_decisions.new_description: Ripples in spacetime produced by accelerating masses, such as merging black holes, neutron stars, or other compact objects.
executed_decisions.justification: After splitting off merger events, the remaining entity is the physical phenomenon of gravitational waves, so the class should be renamed and grouped under a general gravitation/relativity class group.

executed_decisions.justification: The split-out class specifically represents compact-object merger events that generate gravitational waves and belongs under the same broader gravitation/relativity domain.
The LIGO observatory and the 2015 gravitational-wave discovery are part of the same scientific domain as other gravitation and general relativity phenomena, so they should share the same class group.
Gravitational time dilation is a core prediction of general relativity and fits naturally within a Gravitation and General Relativity class group shared with related gravitational phenomena.
General gravity and the gravitational pull of black holes are central gravitational phenomena and should be grouped with other classes under a unified Gravitation and General Relativity class group.
